												If I could describe Earthlock in a single sentence it would be something along the lines of this: A simple, unpretentious rpg heavily inspired by NES/SNES jrpgs. The game has numerous flaws, but if you temper your expectations you'll be taken on a rather enjoyable journey.I'll begin with the game's strengths. The music is absolutely brilliant. Almost every track fit right in and strengthened the atmosphere of the entire game. The dynamic music, how the overworld track would go right into the combat version of a song then seamlessly right back out once combat ended, was a great touch.The story is simple. This is actually a boon to the game as it keeps the focus where it needs to be. The characters all have their reason for going on the journey, and it's never hard to follow.The world is pleasant to look at. Visual design for most places ranges from 7/10 to 10/10. I do not know if it was intended, but the stark contrast in appearance between the ancient technology and the modern, rediscovered/reinvented technology was pleasing. The world felt as fresh and unique as it needed to be. In addition there are lots of little bits of lore scattered around for those who wish to look. Even the character Gnart, a scribe of sorts, keeps a little journal of the adventure one can read at any time. You can tell they cared enough to flesh out their world beyond what the story required.There are many great systems similar to those used in other rpgs. There are no random encounters, all enemies being visible on all maps. One can choose to engage a large group or lure them off one at a time. There are benefits to both approaches. Obviously fighting fewer enemies at a time will make life easier, but fighting more builds a large experience multiplier skyrocketing levels much faster. It's a great risk vs reward system. Although the difficulty spikes make it near manditory to fight large groups when you can or else you may have to go back to grind levels later.You have a party of 4 out of possible 6 characters. Each character can be 'paired' to any other and they work together. They gain passive bonuses based on their bond level, which can change up how they play. Furthermore every character has two seperate stance which give them multiple different abilities. You can have the character Amon play as a rogue/thief, or as a ranged heavy hitter.Instead of physical equipment, each character has a large talent board. On the talent board you can put stat cards, ability cards, and perk cards. This further changes the way characters can play, though each one is locked into a general role. The mages are never going to be as effective fighters as the characters made for it, but they can be made somewhat passable if one chooses.The use of teleport and saving statues is nice. They're well placed so one is never far from being able to save or teleport back to a town, so the lack of being able to save anywhere was not noticed at all.The gardening is a cute addition. I mean that both literal and sarcastically. It's not required except to craft healing potions, or if you plan on turning either of the two character with ranged weaponry into ranged specialists. It is the only reliable way to gain potions or ammunition, and can be quite time consuming. Perhaps being able to purchase second best ammunition and potions from shops would alleviate the frustration I had with the game design behind it. Using it to craft the best items would give incentive, while giving the second best items to shops would have made it 100% skippable by those not wanting to touch it. The enemy visual design is a little hit and miss. In general I like it, even though there's not a wide variety of enemies so some models are simple retextures. I adored the old enemies from the ancient ruins.Now the bad. Like I said the flaws are numerous but most are relatively minor, considering the small team and inexperience behind the people involved. Some minor spoilers about characters lie below, but nothing pertinent to the story.The scope felt a little bit too big for the story. There wasn't a whole lot of character interaction, and I could feel any footing of investment I had in a few of the characters slip as time went on. Gnart and Amon end up being the most interesting of all the characters. That's not to say the others couldn't potentially be, but there is so little ever mentioned of them that it's easy to forget that they are more than cardboard cutouts holding weapons. Olia, a mysterious spear wielding warrior/scholar, obviously has an interesting backstory that is constantly hinted at, but never properly told. Taika is an odd and special breed of magic dog, but we're never told what makes them special. PAT is an ancient robot from the pre-magic-apocalypse, but he tells almost nothing of interest before that pre-magic-apocalypse. I think Ive is my least favorite character, but that may be because of her introduction to the game and lack of consequences for a particular action she commits rather than her demeanor. The game shares a lot of backstory on Amon and Gnart, on the other hand. While it serves to flesh them out a lot and is wonderful in and of itself. It also highlights just how little the game tells us of the others. In short, I think the characters have character, but the lack of interaction makes one easily forget.The dialogue is also rather simple and a little strange at times. Some of it could be due to translation, but it never bothered me personally.In addition I wish there was just more interaction between all the characters. They all had their various reasons for being dragged into this adventure, but the party banter felt very lacking. Maybe an easy solution to this could have been various interactions on the Isle of Plumpet (your home base more or less) depending on how far into the story you are. Interactions with things leading the chosen leader of your party to comment with their thoughts or feelings. The fights, or rather the game difficulty, seemed very spotty. You're driven in a linear fashion through the world, or else this wouldn't be much of an issue. However more than a few times you'll enter an area or find a new boss, and there is no way forward except to go back and grind out a level or two. Maybe it was because sometimes I preferred to not fight large groups of enemies so I became underleveled, but even so it was an annoyance. In addition, the AI seems really bad. For example, it will bring a character to the brink of death and then focus on another before actually finishing said character. Animations are a little clunky and character models felt stiff. In contract to the music work, the sound design for everything else was mediocre. This is very spoilerific for the ending, so reader be warned. I'm wondering how the party managed to escape the memory of Maato after destroing the Valvur'ed Ichabo. To my knowledge there was no proper way to leave once you entered. Them just magically pooping out after winning the fight seemed very hamfisted. I can forgive everything else in the game, but that was one thing I felt really needed an explanation. Perhaps this is due to the general feeling of the scope of the game being slightly larger than what the devs could feasably pull off, which I feel is the reason for a lot of other story/character interaction related things. But still, this if anything needed some sort of explanation.In short, the story is nothing spectacular but passable and unpretentious. The game systems are hit and miss, but with a lot of novel things thrown in. The world and music are delightful. I paid around 27 euros for this game. I'd say it's at best a  15 euro title, for those that like this sort of game. Although I feel no regrets paying the amount I did and am glad the money went to this studio. There was real talent and real love fueling this game. Despite the pockmarks and cracks, I found it to be a great experience.

												This game is clearly made with effort. The art assets, especially the environments, are wonderful, the characters each have some interesting mechanic to play around with, and the monster designs are cool. It harkens back to slightly older JRPGs with its use of classic tropes and terribly named inconsequential objects. The mechanics for the battle system are interesting, and at times quite fun.However, this game has so many problems, I cannot in good faith reccomend it.The writing is entirely devoid of voice. Each character sounds like the same person's speech, with a few quirks hastily pasted onto them. What could be relevant and relatable character designs are ruined by one-dimensional exposition lines and a lack of reactive dialogue. The tutorial messages placed into character dialogue are arguably worse, taking what could be an opportunity for cheeky 4th wall breaking, and removing all flavor.The navigation is inconsistent at best. There are areas of the game where you are able to walk into invisible holes in the ground, with your only recourse being to redo your past 20 minutes of progress by loading a previous save. In most places, the character models are prone to get stuck on corners of walls and whatnot.The progression could be interesting, but it takes a good deal of grinding the thief's Steal ability on different enemies to craft objects needed to use the talent points you have gained, and oft creates spaces within the game where the player is underpowered and overleveled when facing enemies, and leads to a less-than-smooth leveling experience.I found the puzzles quite boring. Not very good by any stretch. Many of them will require that your have a single character selected, something the game only ever mentions once, almost at the very start of the game. Some will require you run into stray geometry until your character finds a hidden passage, and all of them require repeated use of a quite awful context-sensitive interact button.All of that combined with the fact that the game has a number of edge-case bugs which can cause save corruption and crashes.This is not a very good game.I hope that the Developers can learn from the mistakes they made with this game and move on to something greater, because everything in this game reeks of untapped, unpolished potential.

												Nice, old school JRPG that harkens to the some of my favorites like the older Final Fantasies and Dragon Quest.  It does the fundamentals well without trying to do anything too radical or new, just a few twists on the tried and true formula, some of which are brilliantly simple and I think add a lot to the experience.  It is apparent that the whole thing was made with love. The world and soundtrack are beautiful and have a lot of character, but the storytelling is pretty lazy, the characters are a little flat, and a lot of it just feels kind of slapped together.Still, all-told, I'm having a good time exploring their world and beating up cartoon monsters with my rag-tag crew of good guys, which is exactly what I was hoping for.  If you want a laid back jrpg romp, this is a good one.

The last two hours completely destroy anything positive about Earthlock.

Somehow missed the check box, but I received this product for free in order to review:Earthlock: Festival of Magic is a more old-school style turn-based RPG that has some good things going for it as far as originality that make it really stand out.  From the start, the game seems a bit familiar.  I can't really come up with anything to compare it directly with, but it seems to have the makings of a solid game right off.  I'm about three quarters finished now, so I feel pretty comfortable writing a review at this point.  Most of what I'd mention up here in the introduction I've already pointed out below.  While there are some flaws and things I don't particularly care for, the good things override a lot of the negatives in my opinion.  ProsThe graphic style is very appealing.  Reminds me of old RPG games I liked from the late 90's or so, when the more 3D style games started to get popular.  There are many varied areas so far, which is great!  There are some jokes here and there.  Humor is a plus,  generally, so this is welcomed.Some fun side quests and other extras to work on during your journey.  I won't get into any details, but I do enjoy having some extra stuff to do, rather than follow one single linear plot.  Not a ton, but I do like the extras that are added in.Music is nice for the genre of game.  Definitely fits the style, and there is nothing annoying about any as far as I am concerned at least.Easy teleport system to move around from fairly early in the game.  This is helpful moving from point to point easily, and there are a good many spots to jump from.There is a nice multi-level crafting system in the game.  While a lot of what you can create might not be necessary in many cases, some aspects can be pretty handy.  The concept of using talent points on a talent grid and changing your stats and adding to other abilities through the talent points system is a nice idea.  The various cards are also interchangeable between characters for the regular stat ones, and then there are more specialized ones that apply to certain characters in ability and perk nodes.  The system is not too complicated, and simply gaining levels gives you access to more spots you can fill.  As long as it is touching one that is previously activated, you can keep activating more that are further down.There are several informative menus you can check during the game, like a bestiary, tutorial recaps, or journal so you can recall where you were if you stopped, or just got confused or didn't know what to do next, etc.  The bond system is a great addition too that adds to battle customization.  As you pair with another member of the party and fight, you gain up to five levels in the system.  They generally will give passives for whenever the two are paired, so you can mix and match depending on situations.There are various different things you can do in dungeons and places you explore.  I like that it's not just moving from place to place and killing stuff.  It makes it interesting to see new things as you are going through various areas of the game.I like the fact that you can change to a secondary stance depending on the situation.  Sometimes one might be more useful or helpful than another depending on what you are battling.ConsThe difficulty of this game is kind of tedious and there is one.  No changing it in any way.  I found myself having to use a lot of heals on some bosses if I skipped battles, and it kind of makes the game less fun than it could be, since I cannot pick up on particular strategies for certain fights that might make it easier.  I simply seemed to be under-leveled and would need to grind a bit first, or else no strategies would work due to lack of health.  Just a fair warning from my own opinion about this particular facet of play in the game.A slight freeze for a second or two after each super move for me.  It's just a small delay, but it is noticeable.Some sounds are very loud compared to others at times.  This might be a bad thing if you are already playing the game pretty loud and you get hit with one of these.No voices at all.  I think it would be a lot better if this were incorporated into the game somehow.I wish the towns were a little busier and had more activity and size.  They are pretty straight-forward and there isn't much to them besides a path or two.  More would have been nice.Camera at times can be a little tricky, especially near borders of areas.There is no skip screen if you find yourself having trouble over and over at a particular spot.  This could really help out, since there are some difficult bosses with small bits of dialogue.Not much substance to the characters or story so far.  I would have liked to see more interaction between different characters.On one particular boss, $AbilityName came up for one of the moves, and I am not sure if this was intentional or not.  Seems like a bug.  It was a seemingly robotic/golem-like boss, but it was a bit strange to see this.Game glitched out on elevators several times.  Once I had to restart because an elevator went up without me, and I fell through the platform and could never move.  I was just kind of frozen in a dark area after I sort of fell through the bottom of the platform where the elevator had been.  Had to quit out and restart the game up.Expensive price for what is in the game.  It is a good length, but there are other RPGs that are long and much longer and not as expensive, or they have more varied elements involved with the story, characters, and the size of places you explore and visit.   ConclusionAlthough I have quite a list of cons, they are not too bad overall, and the game itself is quite good!  I would not pay anything like the full price if I were buying this, but at a pretty good discount this game is totally worth playing.  I'm really glad I was able to experience this game, and it is a pretty well put together work.It reminds me of some of the older RPGs that I played, but has some extra polish added in graphically, and does some pretty neat things with crafting, as well as combat to make it different than your standard RPG.  The talent point system is an interesting spin as well, and adds a different sort of dimension compared to traditional RPGs.  I definitely recommend this, though it does have some rough spots.  Many who enjoy some of the older games in the genre might appreciate this one a good bit.  All in all, I like what was done in the game.  It's been a pleasure to get to play.  If interested, definitely get it on sale though, if you can.

												Earthlock is a western take on the classic jRPG formula and should be instantly familiar to anyone who enjoys that kind of game. Besides its own charming cast of characters and beautiful world, it has a number of mechanics that set it appart from the rest:Character progression: Characters level up, but unlock skills and talents on a talent board - different talents are collected or crafted, then sloted on the board as the player earns more slots. To use a slot, a character has to have an available point to spend, a talent to place in it, and must have a talent in one of the adjacent slots. There are different types of slots - some reserved for the character's abilities, some for stat boosts, others for passive abilities such as damage reduction, extra damage or the ability to ressurect once per fight.Stances:In combat each character has two stances tehy can switch between. Thus Amon, the main hero, can either be a dagger wielding rogue, able to cloack himself, mug and steal from opponents and slice and dice them, or he can grab his trusty gun and shoot opponents with ammo harvested from his garden (yes, you grow your own ammunition in a garden). Bond:In your party of up to 4 characters, you can pair up sets of characters and their bond will increase, giving them unique boosts whenever these specific two are paired up. It adds another layer to party selection, as you will not only look at what four characters to take along, but also how better to split them into two pairs to gain the bonuses you need in a given situation.On top of that, each pair shares the typical "limit break" style bar used to power specials. So once you can trigger a special, you still have to choose which of the two characters' ability will be more useful.Overall, it is a fun, beautiful little game. It is not the longest, it is not the most challenging, but if you give it a chance, it can offer you fun with some nifty character systems, enjoyable gameplay and some tough boss fights.Backed it on kickstarter and did not regret doing so :)

												Earthlock: Festival of Magic is the game I would reccomend to people who get turned off by staple features of 90s console RPGs.Earthlock manages to lovingly emulate the enjoyment of playstation and SNES RPG Titles, but in a truly surprising way actually progresses and reinvigorates the style. While the titles this game is based on are great, they require those who weren't fans or unable to get past certain pet peeves to put up with it for the entire game.Things like repetitive battle music, slow battles, oversimplified commands (generic Attack command), and the dreaded grinding of fighting the same short encounter list makes classics and modern retro RPGs harder to enjoy for many people. Earthlock addresses all of this while forging it's own identity.The Soundtrack is incredible and diverse, but what makes it more than just nice to listen is that battle themes are rearranged versions of the area themes they belong. It truly makes the game more enjoyable when your favorite battle themes can be traced to fighting in the sewer or on the glacier. But most importantly you never go into the hundreds upon hundreds of battles hearing the same opening over and over, also the switch is seamless as a nice touch.Slow battles is a little harder to explain, but just expect no ATB bars and being able to input commands much faster than most turn based games. In the few instances where the battles drag on a bit, the game shells you a bit of bonus EXP for sticking to the end.Very early the game teaches you a simple trick, slashing attacks kill plant enemies better. From this point on, you realize that the generic attack technically dosen't exist in this game, the game puts it in your best interest to explore and adapt since the stances can radically change your battle strategies and with more useful attack abilites (Gouge, traps) and becuase such logic as only ranged attacks can hit flying enemies, stops the players from mashing an attack command for 40 hours.Last but not least, Grinding. There are too many good games classic and modern that need warning labels about how much they block your progression or enjoyment because of this curse. It seems way too hyperbolic to state that Earthlock simply has no grinding, it techinically does, but with good mechanical and subtle design it never needs to plauge the average player. Encounters are visible and can be avoided or engaged quite easily, but another feature is to lure encounters into 1 large outnumbering battle. When you risk these battles, your exp is dramaticly increased based on the size of the encounters, in fact fighting single enemies produces pitiful gains. In this fashion, the game encourages you to seek battles that might be more than you can chew. You never find yourself fighting the same list of encounters with a static exp increase. A more subtle feature is how the hub garden let's you literally farm for ammo and craft potions, but it's used when players are spending downtime between the more active chunks of the game. Other small things help like getting extra exp for not having anyone die, or making the level cap 20, or how upgrading the bonds gives you points to level up with. The amount of options and characters and pairs, while not staggeringly large, give players lots of room to deal and adapt to bosses and tough areas all the better.In terms of cons this game does have a handful or so. The engine and the collsion can be a little spotty when walking around, the control scheme takes a bit to get used to for using abilities and items, PAT takes a small while before he truly holds up as good as the other characters. A less nitpicking issue is that gold (or as this game labels it Daler) has very very little use in this game thanks to how the garden and crafting system works, or how items worth having are found in chests and at the end of boss battles. The game has some good consumable (non health restoring) items to use, but you never get them outside of the arena, and you cant take them elsewhere, so things that could be bought with currency just dont get to be used for some reason. In the end your Daler becomes obselete really fast, I felt that removing the Daler or making more shops would have integrated Daler perfectly.There's more subjective things to talk about like how the story and characters are begging to have more time in the spotlight at times, or how the game simply dosen't offer optional areas and even a fraction of side content that more popular games offer, But I state that for a kickstarted retro style RPG this is one the most polished and refined original titles to come out of 2016 and for a first time title from a new indie studio in Norway, That is incredible.I (Regrettably) did not kickstart this game and had only found a couple of reviews prior to buying and finishing this game, Therefore most of what I knew going in was minimal at best.

												JRPG's are a rather broad genre, and can focus on quite a few different things. This one is mechanics focused: lots of effort was put into making the battles easy to control and the game itself flows smoothly. The game is "streamlined", in that you don't spend time messing with equipment optimization, but there's still some choices to make with your character progression thanks to the ability to put different kinds of cards on your talent board. Level up, get a point, pick a card and slap it on the board, and you're on your way. Easy and efficient. The battles themselves are the usual turn-based type, and that's a good thing. The main innovation is that you get a multiplying XP bonus based on how many enemies you fight, so you're strongly incentivized to set up huge battles against swarms of enemies. Don't bite off more than you can chew... Mechanics-focused indie RPG's usually don't look like much, and this is the best thing about Earthlock. The game is beautiful, both in terms of the vibrant 3D environments and the high quality JRPG-style music that goes with it. Then there's the parts that didn't get as much attention. Namely, the story and characterization. There seems to be some sort of plot here, but the best thing I can say about it is that it mostly stays out of the way of the actual game. This is not a cinematic or plot driven game of any sort, so if that's what you want from your JRPG's you won't find it here. Likewise, the translation, while competent, is really awkward in some places, and i find the characters to be utterly forgettable.On the balance, I quite like this game. It's exactly what we were promised from Kickstarter: a game that captures the feel of the 3D RPG's of the PS1/PS2 era. And those games weren't exactly famous for their plots or translations either, exceptions excepted. It feels like this game is being overlooked by ... pretty much everyone, and that's a shame.[Disclosure, I recieved this game due to a Kickstarter pledge, which I do not consider to be getting the game for free.]

												This game is pretty awesome overall. I want to start off by saying this game is inspired by the great JRPGs of yesterday, with a unique artstyle and an amazingly genuine and beautiful soundtrack. The mechanics of the game are similair to any JRPG and has many of the tropes expected. The battle system takes a unique position on the stance/position mechanics which is refreshing and makes combat interesting and adds a layer of strategic resource management. Overall battles start out generally pretty easy and ramp up in difficulty in the fist few hours. Enemies are encountered similarily to Chrono Trigger or more specifically The Last Remnant, which is a positive becuase it does away with a bad JRPG trope, random encounters. (Yay)The world is beatifully designed and again the artstyle and colour pallet used fits the experience very well. The game is more vibrant than many RPGs in general and reminds me of Super Giant Games art director Zoe's colour choices for Bastion or Starbreeze's Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons with a bit more variety. It definitely has an indie game vibe about it's aethetics and thats not a bad thing by any means (Unless your a graphics nazi). Overall puzzles are quite easy but fun so solve and treasures are not difficult to find. I was hoping for a more playstation era vibe when it comes to secrets and hidden treasure or quests. Things that take a little more consideration and thought to discover.I love the soundtrack. It is very remenisent of Nobou Uematsu, Yoko Shimomura, mixed with a light version of Darren Korb, also from Super Giant Games (Bastion, Transistor, soon to be Pyre). Each song syncs up with the desired atmoshperic feeling the developers want to convey. I cannot say enough good things about this OST. Eiko Nichols is outstanding in my books.There is a fun crafting/gardening system. Ive never played many traditional JRPGs with a gardening system, let alone one that was simple to understand yet fun to indulge in. Skill/talent/bond systems are quite unqique and allow a degree of customization in where and how you level your stats and abilities. The talent system for example allows you to determine which type of attributes you want to gain depending on your play style, and in turn, your placement of these attributes on a grid system, also determines which abilities you obtain and when. Its not perfect but it is different and does allow some customization. The story so far isn't about crystals, or people being crystals, or searching for crystals so its decent in my books. The writing reminds me of a PS1 era JRP so thats great.Overall the game is very enjoyable. Ultimately its a great first installment in the series that appears to be a light version of a Final Fantasy JRPG type game. I have a lot of faith in this game and this company. Moving forward I know they will improve upon the things mentioned above and continue to produce outstanding experiences.

												EARTHLOCK: Festival of Magic is an adventure RPG game with fantasy themes, and enjoyable single-player gameplay. Earthlock's story is something that I am still learning, but its story takes place in the world of Umbra, where a cataclysmic event occurs that stops the planet from spinning. This leaves part of the world scorched by constant sunlight, part of it perpetually cold due to lack of sunlight, and a patch of livable land in between. The incident ends up burying much of the past advanced civilization, but humanity survives and society begins anew in the habitable part of the planet. The story follows the adventurer known as Amon, a boy from a desert city called Zenit. Although he usually scavenges ruins, he eventually gets entangled in a conflict with a ruling Empire, when his uncle is kidnapped, and an artifact he owns is trying to be taken from him.The game's combat is reminiscent of some older RPG games, and has a turn-based system where each character can choose their attack, magic attack, or buff. There is also an MP system in the game, called Amri, and you must use it in order to use characters' special attacks and magic attacks. There is also a "battle bonds" system that gives passive buffs to characters that fight together over time, and they seem to increase the more battles you do.In its combat, there is an EXP system, and when characters level up, you can apply talents to their talent boards that increase stats, give them a new ability, or give them special defenses and buffs.Earthlock's open-world gameplay is quite fun. In the cities, there are NPCs and buildings that you can visit, as well as some shops in certain areas, but in the overworld areas, there are enemies of numerous kinds, each having their strength and weaknesses. Many of the game's enemies have an elemental weakness and strength, or a weakness to a certain type of attack, be it piercing, slashing, crushing, etc. There are many different types of locations to be found in the game too, from swamps to deserts to temples, and more! The locations and the soundtrack of Earthlock are my favorite aspects of the game, and the environments are beautiful and unique. The game also has a crafting system that allows you to create ammo, potions, spells, talents, resistances, and some other things as well. As you explore the world of Umbra, you'll find various seeds for plants that you can plant when you reach an island in the game, and when grown and harvested from, they provide you with key ingredients that you'll need to make important items. Though the plant-growing and harvesting process can be time-consuming, as long as you have a plant, it will be able to provide infinite resources, and as it levels up to level 3, it will give you more items per harvest than a level 1 plant.So far, Earthlock has been quite enjoyable, although the difficulty curve has been a bit difficult to adjust to, and I'll probably have to do some more grinding. Some of the puzzles can be tricky, as well, but overall, I quite like this game, and I think it should have some more recognition.Previously, I was encountering a glitch where the game would crash often for me. I contacted Snowcastle about the issue, and they released a patch that made it so that the game would work better for Windows 8 users, and I appreciate their efforts a lot, as I haven't had a single crash since then.I do have a few complaints that I have so far in playing Earthlock. There is a difficulty spike after a certain area in the game that other people have noticed as well. You will also likely have to do some grinding of some enemies in order to reach levels that make certain difficult future boss fights doable in a way that gives you a chance. Each boss has a different strategy, and it can be hard to guess what it is sometimes, but after time, you'll be able to find their weaknesses, and with enough patience and levels, you'll be able to finish the fight. Fortunately, the game seems to consistently have save-game statues before every fight, so that you can warp back to the island and rest up, as well as make items you might need, like more potions or ammo.I've also noticed a few issues with the dialogue, and sometimes I feel like the dialogue could be fleshed-out better, but the characters do seem to have their unique personalities.Overall, Earthlock seems to be a very nice game so far, though. The unique and beautiful environments, gameplay, its absolutely lovely soundtrack, character designs, and graphics so far have been very enjoyable and quite nice to experience, and I think that this game is quite fun to play, and it has quite a bit of potential. I hope that the developers can recognize and deal with the difficulty spikes, and make the game a more smooth experience, but I still like the game quite a bit so far, and I do not regret buying it.I would recommend Earthlock to anyone who enjoys RPGs with turn-based combat, and anyone who enjoys open-world adventures. ^.^

Earthlock: Festival of Magic is a simple yet very enjoyable JRPG set in a mystical world of danger and adventure. General GameplayIn Earthlock you’ll play as Amon and his group of have-a-go heroes as they adventure through Umbra. The story is light-hearted but fits well with the JRPG genre and though it isn’t overly ‘deep’, it does the job of keeping you interested in the characters and wanting to find out more as the game goes on. There are some nice bits of lore throughout the game and some character development that, hopefully, will lead into a sequel.The gameplay is intuitive and relatively simple to learn - a huge plus for me is the fact that the game is fairly straightforward. There are dungeons along the way you can explore and you can veer off a little and do you own thing but your direction is clear and the story path is easy to follow.Earthlock uses the usual JRPG turn-based combat style of choosing whether you want to attack/use items/rest and though it seems easy at first, once you start meeting new party members and unlocking new talents and abilities you’ll find yourself having to think about your technique a little more. Your party members can be ‘paired’ and will gain a battle bond whilst they fight together, giving them added passive advantages and a super ability when fully levelled. The combination of skills, abilities and stances gives you a huge arsenal to play how you prefer and allows you to take different approaches to taking on enemies.There is also a fleshed-out levelling system that allows you to pick and choose what you level in what order you want but also allows you to switch out talents/abilities/some stats if you’re not happy with them, if they don’t suit your playstyle or they aren’t working in a specific battle. You ‘craft’ talents which can then be used on any of your characters and also swapped out if you need to. Abilities are found throughout the world and sometimes gained when you level, these are mostly character based and can’t be changed. You can also earn ‘stat slots’ which increase a certain stat (e.g. magic, armour, agility) – this is the only way to buff your stats beside levelling.The graphics aren’t amazing but they don’t feel underwhelming either, they fit with the game style. The little pieces of art on the loading screen are fantastic, I wish there was a little more of it in-game (though there is a comic you can buy that I’m hoping has a similar art style). Pros++ Easy to learn gameplay. Everything is explained as and when you encounter new things.++ Delightful story with likeable characters.++ Intuitive but not overly complex puzzles. None of them are too difficult but not even one feels cheap or easy either.++ One of those games you can find yourself getting lost in for hours – 22 hours playtime in a week.++ Brilliant soundtrack that fits with the game world. I probably spent longer than I should have just planting and harvesting seeds because the music was so relaxing.++ Really nice lore if you take the time to read it which is hopefully continued in the comic. Cons--Cannot skip enemy attack animations. This can become time consuming if you’re like me and prefer to fight a large group for more XP.-- You can only control your camera at certain points in the game, which has led me running into enemy ambushes unintentionally and not being able to see around me properly at times.-- No dungeon mini-maps. My memory is pretty bad so remembering which routes I’ve taken in corridors that all looked the same was kind of hard.-- Can be a little difficult at times with no warning meaning you need to grind up a level or so to pass some of the bosses.-- Little to no replayability. Once the game is over there isn’t really much to do. SummaryOverall, Earthlock is absolutely worth trying, especially if you’re a fan of JRPG’s that are a little more light-hearted. The gameplay is fun, the story keeps you interested and the overall experience is great. I completed the game in a week and had a lot of fun getting all the achievements so I’d happily recommend Earthlock: A Festival of Magic. The ending was fantastic and closed the game perfectly, and has kept me wanting a sequel so I hope these guys have something else coming.

												Okay, this game intrigued me since I first heard about it. As a huge fan of old school JRPGs such as Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest this was right up my alley. So naturally I backed the Kickstarter, and was thrilled when it exceeded funding.I've been eagerly awaiting this game on the same caliber as Dragon Quest VII and Final Fantasy XV. So was it worth it? Oh yes. The game was developed by a small team, so it has that "indie game" vibe to it, but it takes the classic JRPG formula and throws some awesome unique flavor to it. I'm not one to read super long reviews though, or write them for that matter, so here's a list of pros and cons for the gamePros:- The artOh my god is this a beautiful game. The colors, and areas are beautiful, with unique character designs, amazing locales, and an old school overworld. The best part of the already amazing art though, is it's unique style. Unlike many Japanese style RPG styles developed by a small team, it doesn't look like it's stealing it's style from FF, DQ, Tales of, etc.- The battle systemA turn based RPG really has to have a unique battle system to shine, and Earthlock really does. The characters can build bonds between each other through combat, and learn passive abilities. Also in battle every character has two stances, which really makes combat strategic and fun. Also, a lot of turn based RPGs in general suffer from long battle animations which make battle a slog. Not Earthlock. The battles are crisp and smooth, delivering fluid beautiful combat, that flows perfectly, and doesn't slow down the game a bit.- The storyAdmittedly I'm not super far in yet, but it's been very good so far. No JRPG tropes of amnesiacs, destroyed hometowns, awkward romance between childhood friends etc. I'm not quite at the point where the story has "took off" per se, but I have no reason to believe it won't be great.- The charactersOnce again, I don't believe I'm far enough to see the characters truly develop but every character has had a unique personality without relying on a tired trope. Plus there's a character named Frogboy. How can you not love that?- The music The music is absolutely gorgeous and captures the feel of the game perfectly. Like the art style, it's a completely unique style that doesn't feel like an intimation of another game.- The hub islandI'm not a fan of "crafting" games, but the hub island you find a few hours in adds a lot of fun and depth to the game. You can grow plants to craft items from, and as someone who put 100 hours into Stardew Valley, this is an absolute joy to have a Harvest Moon lite thrown into an already very beefy RPG.Cons:- Controller buttons don't appear on screenI'm playing with an XBOX 360 controller, as it's my weapon of choice in my PCMR arsenal. Although the game recognizes it just fine, it shows keyboard buttons instead of the controller buttons in the menu, battles, tutorials, etc. Once again, it doesn't ruin the game by any stretch, as I've gotten used to it, but it's a bit of an annoyance. Hopefully the devs fix this and I can remove this as well.There you have it, overall there's a few small things that annoy me, that hopefully the devs patch out soon. However the pros overwhelmingly outweigh the cons. This game gives me that feeling of excitement, wonder, and awe as I had the first time I played FFIX, and I hope for the devs this can reach "Overwhelmingly Positive" so that they can maybe make a sequel one day.

SnowCastle figured out which buttons to push and they delivered, over and over throughout this game.The Good:The music's fairly good for an indie game; it starts to drone on after a while but it has a lietmotif that is memorable and the transitions are well done.  The scenery is breathtaking and believable from a geological perspective (desert surrounded by mountains, forest in the lowlands, swamp at a river delta).  As an audiovisual experience it hits its mark.The world-building... wow.  While it's a little back-loaded, the creators went out of their way to make the setting robust.  In particular, the game sets about establishing its own idioms and jargon.  A little vocab for your convenience: Lys is the sun, a Cycle is one orbit around Lys, and a Moonrun is equivalent to one day (not a month, as I originally thought).  The concept of Earthlock’s planet Umbra is a heart of fantasy gold: the planet has stopped rotating and one half of it is in perpetual day, while the other is in perpetual night.  They track the passage of time by the movement of the moon (which is implied to circle the planet once a day by our standards).  The game puts a lot of lore in the fire and not all of it comes to fruition… that’s good if it’s the start of a series and I’m hoping that’s the case.Each character has their own flavor… you’re not likely to care for all of them but you will probably like at least one of them.  The game has context-sensitive cutscenes which trigger based on who is leading the party.  As such, you can switch in somebody you like to be your map icon and they’ll get more screentime.  I didn’t care much for the protagonist (Amon) so I had Gnart running around the entire game (Yes, I like piggies).  I thought this was a very novel approach to player preferences and I’d like to see it used in more JRPGs.Combat is excellent: each character has two “stances” which boast a separate set of abilities, doubling the utility of each team member and allowing them to fill two roles.  The aesthetic is sleek and easy to follow; icons on health bars let you know how long an effect will remain and give you the gist of its purpose.  You also have the freedom to customize your character’s stat priorities, so you can create interesting synergy with unusual strategies.  I loaded Gnart with speed-boosting talents and put him into Focus stance: he became a lightning bolt of buffs and whenever somebody else got a turn they hit like a mountain.  There are ways to make any team of four viable which is nice to see; often games with more than three characters will just write some off as throwaways.I have two issues with the combat system I’ll discuss later, but for the most part it was perfect.Random encounters aren’t random (a great move in modern RPGs): you can see opponents on the map and each represents one enemy.  One of the most entertaining components of the game is kiting them around so that more than one enters battle at the same time (which gives a bonus multiplier to experience).Stuff that could use Work:Stances are the big allure of the combat system, which makes it a pity that switching them in combat is so punishing.  Not only do you lose a turn switching stances, but your haste takes a hit and it takes longer to get your next turn.  This is incredibly frustrating and prevents you from switching stances more than a few times the entire game.  To the developers: I’d make normal stance switching accelerated (like the Quick Switch talent) and upgrade Quick Switch to make stance swapping instantaneous.Stances are also particularly punishing for Olia and Gnart: Olia loses her counterattack immediately on switching stance (rather than holding out until her next turn, like it should) and all of Gnart’s buffs fall off the party immediately when he switches stance (something no other buffing character has to deal with).  To the developers: make Olia’s counterattack a one-turn duration refreshing effect and stop removing Gnart’s buffs when he switches to Mage—they’ve already got a timer on them, that’s enough of a power balance.Stuff I’d pass on next time:PAT.  I know it’s a trope of the genre being evoked, but the quirky robot speaking in blips annoyed me.  Personal preference I guess; the bot was viable as a combat option but in dialogue I rolled my eyes every time it talked.Overall the game was very satisfying and difficult to put down.  I’d buy a sequel in a heartbeat… if it had Gnart in it, that is.

												I really love this game, and its universe, but I have a hard time recommending it. EARTHLOCK has some great ideas, but the game is too small, too short, to allow these ideas to breathe. Making them feel halfdone. I'll definitely look forward to any game these guys create in the future. Let me first talk about the combat system; There are 6 characters, each with two different combat-modes that you can switch between. There is also a battle-bond system, you team your party members up 2-and-2 and they'll form a bond. From 1 star to 5 this battle bond unlocks unique passives that strengthen different playstyles. (You can change bonds whenever you want without loosing any progress)There is a third mechanic to the combat system and that is the talent board. Each character has a talent board with set amount of plugs. There are Abilities, Perks and Traits. Perks gives different passives and buffs, Traits give you statpoints and Ability gives you skills you use in your combat-mode. Unlike other talent-tree systems in other games, EARTHLOCK allows you to change what is in the plugs whenever you want. So as you play the game, you'll find new abilities that you can change out the ones you already have. Meaning if you prefer one battle-mode over the other you can build your talent-board around this.The negative to this is that there isn't enough options, making the system feel halfdone, or too big for the game. Throughout the game, you feel you have options, you're finding skills and changing them out. But in the end, there's barely any choices. Not to mention the characters whose second combat-mode is simply buffs, The universe is beautiful, with no UI when walking around you get to truely appreciate the backgrounds and the details the developers have put into it. And god! Some scenes are amazing. But again, it feels rushed. At the beginning, I'd explore like I'd explore a proper rpg: I'd talk to bookshelves and crates lookings for loot and idiotic lines from books. But nothing. I could not interact with anything outside of the quest items, and that felt.. odd to me. It wasn't natural. Especially considering later in the game there WERE bookshelves I could talk to, in the giant library, out of the dusin bookshelves I could talk to TWO. TWO!! Who the heck programmes only two bookshelves to be interactables and not the rest?The game is advertised as an old-school JRPG, and that casuals should look elsewhere. I disagree. Oh how I disagree. This game isn't hard, this game is laughable easy. Sure, sure, if I ran into a boss without healing up or preparing I'll swear and wish there was a flee button so I could prepare myself. Did I die? Sure, yes, of course. But because of my mistakes. Because I tried to avoid mobs and ended up in a combat versus 12 mobs when I had half HP and no ultimate ready. But the combat is easy, tedious at times (considering before Taika my skills would each hit 10%) But slow combat doesn't equal hard combat. Once I unlocked Taika as a party member, the rest of the game became a breeze, only difficulty came from me going for 100% achievements which forced me to run around the game with random characters with random bonds together. I don't know if Taika is simply broken, or if this is some bug. Taika has many AOE skills, if you meet 8+ mobs, Taika will hit them for the normal 10%. But unlike the other few (and rare) aoe skills the other character has, it seems Taikas damage stacks. Thats a bad way of describing it. Normally, an AOE will do X amount of dmg to X character. Taika's skill does XXXX dmg spread out. Meaning if I meet 8 mobs, she'll hit all of them for 10%. But as the mobs die, at the end her skill could one hit a monster. So yes, boss fights became very, very, easy.  (While the other characters aoe would do the same dmg no matter how many or few monsters we encountered)Part of the difficulty of this game is lack of information: There is no information on skills, buffs, debuffs, dmg, or levels. You don't know what level monsters are, and you don't know what that debuff does. Your own skills got descriptions but they are limited. Which meant every time I encountered a new debuff, or buff, it was a trial-and-error playstyle. They had some interesting buffs and debuffs. Like one that reflexs all magical damage onto who casts it. I killed myself once or twice trying to figure out what that new icon under their hp bar meant. But once you figured it out it was "oh I cannot kill him now, I'll just click rest for three more rounds untill it disappear and then kill him".To sum up: + Beautiful universe+ Seemless graphics+ Talent Board, changeable talents+ Garden+ Beautiful graphics.+ No UI (outside of combat).+ Puzzles.+ 6 Characters, 4 party slots.+ Each character has two combat-modes, which you can change between. - Some combat-modes are useless.- No skip-button for scenes- No Flee-button - Cannot sell items to merchants- Advertised as a hard oldschool jrpg, which would have been fine if the game hadn't been so easy. - Unbalanced characters (Compare Taika's AOE with anyone elses AOE) - The game kept trying to babysit me, every time I met a boss, I got a long speech about how this boss might be too hard,  and we might not be able to defeat him and might need to change my tactic. Every time I beat the boss without issues. The large groups of monsters outside were a bigger challenge than the bosses.- A few combat freezes, if I killed too many monsters at once or something there would be a few seconds where nothing happened. Like the game was thinking. Now that's a lot of negative things, so why am I still recommending it? Because it's a beautiful game.I wish the developers would go back and spend another year on it, add another 20 levels and allow us to interact with useless things more. Who knows, maybe they'll add an DLC! I love the universe, I love the frogs, and I like the characters.(Though I wish there were more scenes where the characters interacted with eachother, giving me the time and oppertunity to fall inlove with them. As it is, the ending just made me roll my eyes)

IntroductionEarthlock: Festival of Magic is a classically inspired, turn-based, 3D Adventure RPG. Rather than setting out on the typical cliché RPG quest to the save the world, the ragtag band of misfit characters all have their own reasons to be exploring the world. They simply join each other out of convenience rather than some misguided heroic notion. With the ability to change your stance and thus change your abilities, the combat system in Earthlock: Festival of Magic adds an extra layer of strategy to what otherwise would be common RPG style fights.GameplayEarthlock: Festival of Magic is much like any other RPG of this style that you have played. Your team of up to four characters all head out to the world map to find their way to their current destination. While they all have their own motives and reasons, they will slowly grow bonds between them and be stronger for it. The Bond system is one of the features that sets Earthlock: Festival of Magic apart from other typical Role Playing Games. You can have up to four characters in play at any given time, but there is an extra layer of strategy that will come in to play here as well. Characters are grouped into pairs on the battlefield, and the characters that are paired together will form a bond between them. The longer they are paired, the stronger it will grow and new abilities will be added and talent (skill) allocation points will be earned. This encourages you to not only ensure you keep rotating your partners to make certain they gain all the talent points they can, but also to partner those together that give the best perks for whichever area or battles you are in.Another unique element is the farming system. Rather than just buying your ammunition or items, you have the ability to grow the plants required to produce them yourself. The simple farming system has you finding seeds, planting them in your garden and watering them. One they are ready to harvest, which takes only moments, you can harvest them. The plant itself is not damaged, and will grow again if you water it. Harvesting from a plant a sufficient number of times will cause it to level up or possibly mutate. Leveling up produces more crops per harvest, and a mutation gives a seed for a new variety of that plant. You can then take all your crops you have and craft them into the various ammunition or items you will need during your adventure.As mentioned earlier the game has talent points rather than typical RPG automatic skill increases purely at level up. These talent points allow you to shape your character’s stats and abilities. To upgrade your character, you have a proper tile to place and a talent point to place it. There are some generic tiles that will work for anyone and then there are those that are tailored for specific characters. The generic ones come in two flavours, the one that just boosts your stats, and the other than changes an aspect of the game or adds new abilities. Typically, after a boss battle you will gain one of the latter tiles as well the ability to craft additional units of that tile. The others are commonly found after some battles or in chests.The game is broken into two types of screens: the world map and the zone map. Both are basically the same idea, however, the world map lets you walk between zones, fighting battles on your way, and the zone usually has unique puzzle elements to it as well as the battles. Battles in this game are to some degree optional. If you don’t feel like fighting, you can avoid the enemies as you are able to see them wandering around. Each unit you see walking around the screen is typically a single monster for you to fight. A more unique feature however is the fact that you can deliberately attempt to fight multiple enemies at a time. You simply run past an enemy and have it pursue you until you have wrangled up as many as you are willing to fight. This will make the battle far more challenging than had you soloed them all, but it also gives you bonus experience due to being outnumbered. The battles are a speed-based turn system. You can see the order in which the battle will unfold, and unless an ability is used that slows or speeds up a unit, the order shown will be how the battle will play out. This adds a layer of strategy to the game as you are able to make a plan about who you should be focusing on for your current turn rather than just always targeting the weakest one.There are puzzles in each of the zone maps that you must solve to progress. These puzzles can be as simple as finding the key to unlock a door, or using coloured lights to unlock a device. One zone even had a unique twist where you had to try to make it to the next sliver of shade in order to avoid passing out from the extreme heat of the area. These puzzles add a level of challenge and interest to the game and makes for a more fun experience overall.The game works well with both the keyboard and mouse or with a gamepad. I played it mostly with the gamepad and found it to be highly responsive and worked well with that setup. The interface takes a little getting used to but once you have it figured out, it actually works very well.The only really bad things I have to say about this game is that it requires you to grind a lot of enemies fairly often and that you can't usually rotate the camera. If you have been attacking single enemies everywhere you went, you will be in severe trouble when the boss shows up. Even if you have been heavily overwhelming yourself by wrangling every enemy you can into battle, you will still have trouble when the boss shows up. This leads you to need to waste time fighting the same groups of enemies repeatedly until you gain enough levels to be able to struggle your way past the boss. Some might argue that bosses should be extremely challenging, and while I might agree, having to redo the battle repeatedly and getting lucky is far less fun than having a fair shot at killing the boss due to being a sufficiently high level to face it in the first place.Graphics and SoundThis is a very charmingly cartoonish looking game. The visuals really do fit well with this style of game and is sure to have nostalgic appeal to those of us who played games at the turn of the millennia. Each area you visit also has its own design and look to it which greatly enhances the experience. No two areas really look that much alike and it shows that a lot of care and attention to detail went into the planning of the graphic designs of the game. The enemies on the other hand are not that varied in design. While there are plenty of enemies in this game for you to fight, there are quite a few that are just recolours of ones you previously fought. This leads you to fighting pretty much the same enemies everywhere you go with a few new ones tossed into the mix. It’s mildly disappointing, but is something that is common to these types of games so it shouldn’t really be considered that much of a detractor.The music is wonderful and really helps with the charm and appeal of the game with each area pretty much having its own theme music. For the most part, the sound effects are your standard RPG ones that are common to the genre. There is a distinct lack of voice acting in the game which I am not sure if it was done to add to the late 1990s feel of the game where speaking wasn’t that common, or if it was simply because they didn’t have the ability to record all the dialogue with the budget they had for the game. I know I always prefer it when the characters talk aloud in games, however at the same time I wouldn’t avoid a game for lacking that feature. Plus this way it avoids the risk of having a really annoying sounding character spoiling your experience!Overall Earthlock: Festival of Magic is a welcome addition to the RPG Adventure games available on Steam and has enough unique elements to it that I found it to be quite enjoyable.

												I have played the game for 75 hours on Xbox One. Don't let the time played fool you. Here is a nice video preview which I made which'll help you decide if you want it or not.


YouTube™ Video: Earthlock: Festival of Magic Gameplay and Preview - September Games with Gold (Xbox One) 

			Views: 22,580		

			In this video, we show a preview of the game ‘Earthlock: Festival of Magic’ for Xbox One and Steam. Video was Recorded and Voiced by The Hidden Levels one and only Manic Ado.		

 Positives:Music is beautiful – Through the most RPG games I play the music is always top notch and beautiful. Earthlock is no exception to this and provides a beautiful soundtrack to go a long with the game. Although the soundtrack is nowhere near the level of Final Fantasy or any other big RPG games, it was still enough for me to highly praise and enjoy it.A great RPG experience – Earthlock is everything you seek from a more ‘classic’ RPG experience. This game is turn based and relies mostly on strategy. You are level capped at 20 and towards the near end of the game the enemies get tenaciously strong. If you don’t pay attention then it’s easy to get a party wiped and hit a game over screen. There aren’t any voice overs in the game and it relies more on just being able to read the text on the screen as it pops up. I preferred this over the voice acting as it gave me more engagement. Not the farming you’d expect – In RPG’s, especially MMO’s farming revolves around killing the same monster repetitively in the hopes of getting rare loot. Earthlock however takes the meaning literally as you have farm land in which you can plant seeds and then harvest them for materials when they are ready. I spent quite a lot of time doing farming because I enjoyed the relaxed style of it. Character change – This is a really minor positive but one I enjoyed. I really liked how you could swap between characters when in the actual game. In some instances this required swapping to a smaller character to get to a place inaccessible by other characters.Unique Talent and levelling system – For each character you are presented with a board full of squares where each time you  level up you get a talent point and can put a talent card in an empty square. You can also get talent points by levelling up bonds with each characters and certain squares required skills which you can find the cards in loot and chests. Negatives:Selecting an enemy to hit – Depending on your camera angle, choosing an enemy to hit can be frustrating and annoying at times because it’s super sensitive and only rotates to certain characters. This sometimes left me hitting myself and healing enemies.A lot of the NPCs are just filler – Most the NPCs in the town just wander around aimlessly providing no text option or talk. Even in certain cities they were walking around and into each other stuck in an endless cycle of doom. The walking detection on them was very poor.Camera Angles – The camera angles on the game are not so great. It uses the fixed camera pivoting in one position. On some scenes this caused a huge amount of frustration and some scenes where running into a blind corner led into me running straight into enemy mobs.No option to sell – Being a hoarder sometimes I would get duplicates of items I wouldn’t want duplicates of, for instance seeds and recipes. I wish there was an option to sell so I could sort my inventory out perfectly the way I want things.No minimaps – The only map on the Earthlock is the overworld map. I would’ve loved if they had an area map too with the location name. For instance, I had no idea where “Konkylian Plains” were and when referencing a boss is located there makes it hard to find.You. Are. Dead – Later on in the game there is Ice Regions of Nunaar Station. This part of the game is absolutely dreadful and almost ruined my entire experience of the game due to frustration and unfairness. The enemies are mobbed together in clumps meaning there is no way to sneak around very well or escape them and you will most likely fight between six to eight enemies per fight. These monsters are overpowered with deadly aoes and a very high attack speed that even when it was their turn I knew my maxed characters were going to die. The sound of ice constantly crunching and crackling was a very big nuisance and one which I did not like, I had to mute the games audio.Conclusion:Overall, I really enjoyed my time playing Earthlock and it provided me my fix of turn based RPG games which I really missed due to them being viewed as “outdated” or “old”. Earthlock was not brilliant and certainly flawed at times but I still enjoyed the experience it provided and really enjoyed my time playing it. I hope that more developers will follow suit in making turn based RPGs and not describe the genre as “outdated” or “old” because they simply aren’t. We also found out earlier this year with another game “I am Setsuma” which was another great example of the turn based RPG games really excelling.

												What a pleasant surprise this game was. I will admit, several red flags were raised prior to me buying this game. The $30 price tag, mixed reviews, Kickstarter, Unity Engine... But on the promise that it would take me back to old JRPGs I played as a kid, I decided to give Earthlock: Festival of Magic a chance. And I'm glad I did.Before the review proper I want to thank Snowcastle Games for putting so much effort into something that could easily have been one of many failed Kickstarter projects. I truly hope the small downsides and problems this game have will be fixed in the upcoming sequels. You guys said there was going to be a trilogy and I hope you stick to it.Now, for my somewhat lengthy review:The game is wonderfully crafted. You can tell a lot of effort went into the scenarios and the soundtrack. The art itself may not be for everyone, but it's hard to deny they knew what they were doing when they decided for it. The game, as stated, plays as an oldschool JRPG, so a few modern day luxuries, such as quick saving / save anywhere, are absent. But thankfully we don't have to deal with random encounters.Combat is surprisingly challenging, truly a remnant from bygone eras. I don't remember the exact line spoken by a game character, but it was something like "a hammer and a key can be used to open a lock; both work, but one makes it significantly easier", and this is what the game promotes. You are given many customisation options and it's up to you to decide which one to use for each boss. Expect a few game overs every now and then. The little tune that plays in the game over screen is also lovely, you almost forget this is your 4th failed attempt on the same boss.The story, which is what I value the most in a game like this, is a bit lacking. If you're a hardcore RPG fan like me, there is nothing you haven't seen elsewhere. You have the main character with a hidden past, a strong independent female co-lead who is not very good at being strong or independent, a few mascots, and a bad guy trying to take over the world. It's all here. The characters' backgrounds are mostly left unanswered.At the time of this review, there was a comic book DLC telling the story of two of them, which is not something I agree with, but it's something, I guess. It says comic book #1, so I assume there are more coming, which will rack up the final price considerably, for something that should have been in the game from the start.The game is also very short, with very little side stuff to do, and zero replay value. Took me 20 hours to clear the game with 100% achievements. And that's counting all the game overs. For $30 it might not sound like such a good deal, and this, along with the cliche story and DLC character stories, made me want to give a negative review, but I'd still reccomend it if you get it in a sale, or as a gift. It's a fun little adventure regardless.

												I backed this game on kickstarter on a whim. I liked the cutesy artstyle and felt like playing a classic RPG again, so I just pressed the button and prepared for a let-down. Fortunately, I was proven wrong. The developers gave frequent updates, reacted to bug reports and criticisms (although one bug in particular, that you can fall through the ground on plumpet island on occasion, hasn't been fixed in the finished game) and delivered a finished game more or less on schedule. That alone almost deserves a recommendation. But how is the game?Let's be honest, it is not brillant. But I still enjoyed it.The story is pretty lacking. There is no voice acting, so the story is conveyed through speech bubbles, and since no one wants to read endless dialogue, there is not much to it. There are some books you can read for some additional lore but there is no rich story to be found. There are still some bugs, the aformentioned falling through the ground on plumpet island, and the game gets slower the longer you play. It also crashed a couple of times. But I didn't encounter any game braking bugs or save corruptions so it is definitely playable. I really enjoyed the artstyle, you can see it in the trailer and the pics, so see for yourself if it appeals to you. The background music was varied and relaxing, no complaints there. I liked the actual gameplay quite a lot. The fighting system is pretty straightforward. I strongly recommend playing with a controller, though (I used an xbox controller). The talent system allows you to give your characters different perks (mostly partial immunity against different attack types, strengthening different attack types, but also some special ones) and character upgrades (defence, offence, evasion, quickness, accuracy) and you can also add new abilities that you can find along the way. There is also a bond system: Depending on which two characters you pair with each other they gain different perks which can be quite powerful. You have 6 characters to choose from (you fight with 4). Taken all together, you have quite a large variety of fighting styles, whether you want to be more defensive or offensive, rely more on physical attacks or magic, melee or ranged or area of effect attacks, it is all up to you. All 'talents' (perks, abilities, upgrades) can be exchanged at any time so you can experiment quite easily and even adjust them to a particular boss fight if you want. I recommend the game for people who like classic RPGs, enjoy the artstyle and are looking for a not-too-complex game that still provides lots of variety in fighting styles. I would wait for a sale, though, 28 Euros are a bit steep, in my opinion.
